replace.to: ( C_{\max} or L_{\max} or \sum U_j or \sum T_j or \sum w_jC_j or \sum w_jU_j or \sum w_jT_j or \sum w_jC_j )
In a machine problem with time-lags for every job pair $i\prec j$ in the precedence relation, job $j$ can start only at least $l_{ij}$ units after the completion of job $i$. Default timelag is zero.
A single server is loading the job $J_j$ or operation $O_{ij}$ on the machine which requires a setup time. These setup periods cannot overlap.

In a machine problem with communication delay for every job pair $i\prec j$ in the precedence relation, if the jobs are executed on different machines, then job $j$ can start only at least $c$ units after the completion of job $i$. Default communication delay is zero.

choice.explanation: This webpage will show only a few search options
This webpage will show all search options
Single machine.
Parallel identical machines. We are given $m$ machines. Processing time of job $j$ is $p_j$, independent of the machine.
Related machines. We are given $m$ machines, each with given speed $s_1,\ldots,s_m$. Processing time of job $j$ on machine $i$ is $p_j/s_j$.
We are given $m$ unrelated machines. Processing time of job $j$ on machine $i$ is some given length $p_{ij}$.
Open shop. Every job $j$ consists of $m$ operations $O_{ij}$ for $i=1,\ldots,m$. The operations can be scheduled in any order. Operation $O_{ij}$ must be processed for $p_{ij}$ units on machine $i$.
Flow shop. Every job $j$ consists of $n_j$ operations $O_{ij}$ for $k=1,\ldots,m$, to be scheduled in that order. Operation $O_{ij}$ must be processed for $p_{ij}$ units on machine $i$.

Job shop. Every job $j$ consists of $n_j$ operations $O_{kj}$ for $k=1,\ldots,n_j$, to be scheduled in that order. Operation $O_{kj}$ must be processed for $p_{kj}$ units on a dedicated machine $\mu_{kj}$ with $\mu_{kj}\neq \mu_{k'j}$ for $k\neq k'$.
Arbitrary number of machines $m$.
m=2 machines.
m=3 machines.
m=4 machines.
m=5 machines.
Unlimited number of machines available.
No robot
We are given a single robot that can transport the operations of a job from one machine to another. The robot can make at most one transportation per time.
No server
Single server.
The input consists of only 2 jobs.
The input consists of only 3 jobs.
The input consists of only k jobs.
The number of jobs is at least the number of machines minus one.
No precedence relation.
Given general precedence relation. If $i\prec j$ then starting time of $j$ should be not earlier than completion time of $i$.
Given precedence relation in form of chains (indegrees and outdegrees are at most 1).
Given general precedence relation in form of a tree, either intree or outtree.
Given general precedence relation in form of an intree (outdegrees are at most 1).
Given general precedence relation in form of an outtree (indegrees are at most 1).
Given general precedence relation in form of a collection of intrees and outtrees.
Given precedence relation in form of a series parallel graph.
Given precedence relation where the longest directed path is bounded by a constant.
Given precedence relation where each vertex of a given level l (i.e. the length of the longest directed path starting from this vertex is l) is a predecessor of all the vertices of level l-1.

Given precedence relation for which one can associate to each vertex an interval in the real line, and there is a precedence between x and y if and only if the half open intervals x=[s_x,e_x) and y=[s_y,e_y) are such that e_x is smaller than or equal to s_y.
Quasi-interval orders are a superclass of interval orders defined in Moukrim: Optimal scheduling on parallel machines for a new order class, Operations Research Letters, 24(1):91-95, 1999.

Over-interval orders are a superclass of quasi-interval orders defined in Chardon and Moukrim: The Coffman-Graham algorithm optimally solves UET task systems with overinterval orders, SIAM Journal on Discrete Mathematics, 19(1):109-121, 2005.
Am orders are a superclass of over-interval orders defined in Moukrim and Quilliot: A relation between multiprocessor scheduling and linear programming. Order, 14(3):269-278, 1997.

A divide-and-conquer graph is a subclass of series-parallel graphs defined in Kubiak et al.: Optimality of HLF for scheduling divide-and-conquer UET task graphs on identical parallel processors. Discrete Optimization, 6:79-91, 2009.
A 2-dimensional partial order is a k-dimensional partial order for k=2.

A poset is a k-dimensional partial order iff it can be embedded into the k-dimensional Euclidian space in such a way that each node is represented by a k-dimensional point and there is a precedence between two nodes i and j iff for any dimension the coordinate of i is smaller than or equal to the one of j.
no time lags
unit time lags. TIMELAG
job independent time lags. TIMELAG
job independent negative time lags. TIMELAG
job independent positive time lags. TIMELAG
arbitrary time lags. TIMELAG
arbitrary negative time lags. TIMELAG
arbitrary positive time lags. TIMELAG
no communication delay
unit communication delay. COMMUNICATIONDELAY
communication delay. COMMUNICATIONDELAY
no transportation delays
Between the completion of operation $O_{kj}$ of job $j$ on machine $k$ and the start of operation $O_{k+1,j}$ of job $j$ on machine $k+1$, there is a transportation delay of at least $t_{jk}$ units.
Between the completion of operation $O_{kj}$ of job $j$ on machine $k$ and the start of operation $O_{l,j}$ of job $j$ on machine $l$, there is a transportation delay of at least $t_{jkl}$ units.

Machine dependent transportation delay. Between the completion of operation $O_{kj}$ of job $j$ on machine $k$ and the start of operation $O_{k+1,j}$ of job $j$ on machine $k+1$, there is a transportation delay of at least $t_{k}$ units.

Machine pair dependent transportation delay. Between the completion of operation $O_{kj}$ of job $j$ on machine $k$ and the start of operation $O_{l,j}$ of job $j$ on machine $l$, there is a transportation delay of at least $t_{kl}$ units.

Job dependent transportation delay. Between the completion of operation $O_{kj}$ of job $j$ on machine $k$ and the start of operation $O_{l,j}$ of job $j$ on machine $l$, there is a transportation delay of at least $t_{j}$ units.

Job dependent transportation delay out of two values. Between the completion of operation $O_{kj}$ of job $j$ on machine $k$ and the start of operation $O_{l,j}$ of job $j$ on machine $l$, there is a transportation delay of at least $t_{j}\in\{T_1,T_2\}$ units.

Uniform transportation delay. Between the completion of operation $O_{kj}$ of job $j$ on machine $k$ and the start of operation $O_{l,j}$ of job $j$ on machine $l$, there is a transportation delay of at least $T$ units.

Uniform transportation delay. Between the completion of operation $O_{kj}$ of job $j$ on machine $k$ and the start of operation $O_{k+1,j}$ of job $j$ on machine $k+1$, there is a transportation delay of at least $T$ units.

Job dependent Symmetric transportation delay. Between the completion of operation $O_{kj}$ of job $j$ on machine $l$ and the start of operation $O_{l,j}$ of job $j$ on machine $l$, there is a transportation delay of at least $t_{jkl}$ units, which equals $t_{jlk}$.

Symmetric transportation delay. Between the completion of operation $O_{kj}$ of job $j$ on machine $k$ and the start of operation $O_{l,j}$ of job $j$ on machine $l$, there is a transportation delay of at least $t_{kl}$ units, which equals $t_{lk}$.
no release dates
Job $j$ cannot be scheduled before given release time $r_j$.
This is an online problem. Jobs are revealed at their release times.
no preemption
Jobs can be preempted and resumed possibly on another machine. Sometimes also denoted by 'prmp'
Jobs can be preempted and restarted from the beginning. Sometimes called preemption with restarts as opposed to preemption with resume.
no due dates
Common due date $d$ to every job. Can be a deadline depending on the objective function.
The span between deadline and release time of every job is at most 2. These are called 2-bounded instances.
The span between deadline and release time of every job is at most 3. These are called 3-bounded instances.
The span between deadline and release time of every job is at most 4. These are called 4-bounded instances.
no recirculation
Recirculation, also called Flexible job shop. The promise on $\mu$ is lifted and for some pairs $k\neq k'$ we might have $\mu_{kj}= \mu_{k'j}$.

field.name: no-wait
field.requires: advanced and (O or F or J)

choice.explanation: no no-wait
The operation $O_{k+1,i}$ must start exactly when operation $O_{k,i}$ completes. Sometimes also denoted as 'nwt'.

field.name: no-idle
field.requires: advanced and (O or F or J)

choice.explanation: no no-idle
No machine is ever idle between two executions.
arbitrary processing times
Unit processing times.
Every job has processing time either 1 or 2.
Equal processing times. All processing times are equal to some given $p$.
Equal processing times. All processing times are equal to some given $p$.
Unit processing times.
Restricted machine model. Every job j comes with a set of machines on which it is allowed to be scheduled. Sometimes also denoted as machine environment B.
All operations of a same job $j$ have the same processing time.
Multiprocessor tasks on identical parallel machines. The execution of job $j$ is done simultaneously on $size_j$ parallel machines.
Multiprocessor tasks on identical parallel machines. Some jobs need all machines in parallel for their execution, some need only a single machine.
Multiprocessor tasks. Every job $j$ is given with a set of machines $fix_j\subseteq\{1,\ldots,m\}$, and needs simultaneously all these machines for execution. Sometimes also denoted by 'MPT'.
Multipurpose machines. Every job $j$ needs to be scheduled on one machine out of a given set $M_j\subseteq\{1,\ldots,m\}$. Sometimes also denoted by 'M_j'.
no batching

Serial batching. The jobs have to be processed in batches. The processing time of a batch is the total processing time over all jobs in the batch. If a new batch is started, a constant setup time $s$ occurs.

Parallel batching. The jobs have to be processed in batches. There is no limit on the number of jobs in a batch. The processing time of a batch is the maximal processing time over all jobs in the batch. If a new batch is started, a constant setup time $s$ occurs.

Parallel batching. The jobs have to be processed in batches. A batch consists of maximal b jobs. The processing time of a batch is the maximal processing time over all jobs in the batch. If a new batch is started, a constant setup time $s$ occurs.
no setup
unit setup times.SETUP
unit setup times.SETUP
equal setup times. SETUP
equal setup times. SETUP
Makespan. Minimize the maximum completion time over all jobs.
Santha Claus. Maximizes the minimum machine load.
Sum of completion times. $C_j$ denotes the completion time of job $j$ in some schedule. The goal is to minimize the total completion time.
Weighted sum of completition times. Every job $j$ is given a priority weight $w_j$. $C_j$ denotes the completion time of job $j$ in some schedule.
Maximum flow time. The flow time of a job is difference between its completion time and its release time, i.e. $F_j=C_j-r_j$. The goal is to minimize the maximum flow time over all jobs.
Total flow time. The flow time of a job is difference between its completion time and its release time, i.e. $F_j=C_j-r_j$. The goal is to minimize the total flow time over all jobs.
Weighted flow time. Every job $j$ is given a priority weight $w_j$. The flow time of a job is difference between its completion time and its release time, i.e. $F_j=C_j-r_j$.
Maximum weighted flow time. Every job $j$ is given a priority weight $w_j$. The flow time of a job is difference between its completion time and its release time, i.e. $F_j=C_j-r_j$.

Maximum lateness. Every job $j$ is given a due date $d_j$. The goal is to minimize $\max_j C_j-d_j$ where $C_j$ is the completion time of job $j$. By the use of binary search, this objective is essentially equivalent with testing feasibility when $d_j$ represent strict deadlines.
Throughput. Every job is given a due date $d_j$. The goal is to maximize the number of jobs that complete on time.
Weighted throughput. Every job is given a due date $d_j$. The goal is to maximize the total weight of jobs that complete on time.
Maximum tardiness. Every job $j$ is given a due date $d_j$. The goal is to minimize $\sum_j \max\{0, C_j-d_j\}$ where $C_j$ is the completion time of job $j$.

Weighted maximum tardiness. Every job $j$ is given a due date $d_j$. The goal is to minimize $\sum_j w_j \max\{0, C_j-d_j\}$ where $C_j$ is the completion time of job $j$ and $w_j$ its priority weight.
Arbitrary given number of machines
Fixed number of machines

reduction.explanation: processing times $p_{ij}=\infty$ can be used to encode $M_j$ for every machine $i\not\in M_j$.
